1.title: Who will it be?

11.content:
1. Chris is a 18 year old human. He lives in a small town at the roots of a mountain range bordering the human territory. Chris lost his parents long ago and his uncle took him in. His parents where killed by monsters (thats what he's told but he does not believe that.) He spent most of his childhood in the mountains caves playing with all manner of monster races so he has grown to like most monsters. His uncle passed away 2 years ago but left every thing to Chris, which includes his Basic Goods shop.

2. Elisabeth is 17 year old human living in the Capital city of Dawnwake called Dawnwake. She lives with her older sister Kira (21 years old). She works at the local inn. Her parents where killed by bandits when her family where moving to the capital.

3. Arira is a 25 year old human. She works as a soldier in the north borders and sees a lot of action. As a soldier she lives with other soldiers.

4.Frender is a 23 year old diplomat. His life involves constant traveling from different parts of the empire and sometimes into unknown territory. He has a difficult time because of the war and has to have constant protection. However is is part of a secret group called Crimson Shield . (Crimson Shield want humans to coexist with the other races of Dawnwake and are obligated to stop humans from killing the said races)

5. other

111.content:
Chris stared at the blank page and it stared back. Chris had completely lost his train of thought."God this is not my day!" exclaimed Chris as he slammed his quill into the oak table. "I've got all my notes on the many races of Dawnwake but I just can't seem to start this book" Chris spent most of his childhood with the races and creatures of Dawnwake. Taking notes and documenting them had become a hobby of his however over the past 2 years, after his uncles death he had to spend more and more time at his shop."I will start again tomorrow". Getting up from his chair Chris then proceeded to walk over to his draws, he pulled out a blue shirt and brown trousers and began to dress himself. Looking over at his mirror to check his hair he took a moment to look over himself. Chris stood at 5 foot 10, with a slightly tanned complication, his brown hair was just long enough to hide his eyes from view but if you push back his brown hair you would come to see his turquoise green eyes.

"Chris are you here?" called a familiar voice from inside the shop. "I will be with you in a minute" Chris shouted back. Chris raced down the stairs and through a heavy looking door with a iron deadbolt haphazardly nailed to it. Chris came to a screeching halt almost trapping over his wolf sized dog ironically named Tiny for being the smallest of the litter. Chris looked up after cursing Tiny to come face to face with Ben his closest friend. Ben was around Chris's height, who was taller was open for debate, however this did course a lot of childish arguments between them. Chris and Ben looked very similar and there was a roamer that they where in-fact twins, this roamer was what started there friendship. The only major difference was that Ben possessed jet black hair. "Chris I have bad news" "what is it?"Chris asked back. "Its the Imperial soldiers. They have decided to remove the Lamia's living within the caves to the North"

"What when did they decide this?"questioned Chris "I heard that the king has been ordered the removal. I only over heard one of the soldiers at the barracks complaining about not being involved in the attack and something about cheese. When i asked him about it all he told me was that they left about half an hour ago"explained Ben. "They should be at the caves by about now" Ben then looked over at Chris, Chris's face was unreadable like many times before Ben was unsure what his friend would do next. "umm Chris what should we do?" asked Ben "there's only one thing we can do......
111.title: The biggest decision of Chris's life

choices: Try to get the young lamia out of the caves
1111.content:
...I'm going but your staying here" said Chris "But why?" asked Ben "This is all my fault i was the one who found the Lamia settlement, I was the one who told the elders about it. Its my battle and i don't want you to be dragged into it." explained Chris "I am involved i was with you when you first found them in the caves, i should be there to help you" "Ben I don't want you to get hurt you cant even wield a sword. I'm sorry friend but somethings i must do alone". Ben looked frustratingly at Chris but realized Chris was only trying to protect him, and it was true he could not wield a sword, he almost beheaded Tiny when he first tried to mimic Chris's sword play. "at least let me help get your horse ready" said Ben smirking at Chris "That would be helpful" said Chris smirking back. With that Ben belted out of the back door into the stables behind the shop. "Tiny wake up were going on an adventure". The instant Chris said Tiny, Tiny literally jumped to his feet and ran up stairs, Chris quickly followed suit. As Chris reached his bedroom door Tiny had already pulled out Chris travel pack and weapons. "I really lucked out when i chose you as a pet".

A few minutes later Ben was standing outside with Chris's horse saddled and ready. "Chris where are you?"Ben asked no one in particular "I'm up here" shouted Chris as he lept from his bedroom balcony, as he fell he did a front flip, then landing on his horse. Chris's horse protested at the sudden change in weight."Show off" Ben said as he shock his head. "You better hurry" "don't worry i know a short cut hopefully i will get there before they reach the settlement" with that Chris began to ride the horse up the street towards the mountains followed seconds later by Tiny.

After 10 minutes of fast riding Chris was at 'the short cut' it was a very small opening it was about half a meter wide and just high enough for Chris to stand upright without banging his head. The cave entrance was well hidden by the trees around it and by the way the entrance almost looks like one of the cracks running up and down the mounties. Chris began to hear screams as he entered the caves this accelerated his movements as he pulled his hood over his head to hide his face. Within moments he entered a large cavern that was dimly lit by a few lamps and torches, however Chris could make out at least a two dozen dead Lamia and a few dead soldiers. "shit i was two late" cursed Chris at that point Chris hear more screams and shouts coming deeper within the caverns. Chris ran furtherer into the caverns, and found himself in a cavern smaller then then first. There was 7 dead lamia and 3 soldiers. "I think thats all of them" said the first soldier "the rest of them seem to have gone deeper into the cavern" said the second soldier "I'm sure that they won't be coming back anytime some are. Are work here is done". Chris was standing in the shadows as the soldiers where about to get ready to leave. Chris had a instant feeling and acted apone it but bucking, milliseconds later a blade slices where his neck was. As Chris ducked he began to spin on his toes to face his attacker. Pulling on the hilt of his sword pulling it out with such force that the sword slams the attacker in the stomach. Chris followed through and struck the head of forth soldier that tried to attack him. The soldier was knocked out but this alerted the other three soldier.

Within seconds the soldiers where apone him but Chris had far superior skills and disarmed and neutralized the three without breaking a sweat. "This was all my fault i did this". Chris feel to his knees as he clutch the hilt of his blade. Tiny nuzzles his head under Chris's arm, " Tiny I told you to stay with the horse". Chris sulked in self pity for a few seconds when suddenly Tiny lifted his head and began to bark. "what is it?" said Chris lifting his head slightly. Tiny continued to bark as he got up and ran over to one of the dead Lamia's. Chris got up and followed Tiny, Tiny began to claw at the ground next to the Lamia. Chris with some difficultly pulled the lamia over. the lamia was a young women about 24 years of age with long black hair but what was underneath the dead lamia was a small crack in the wall. In the hole there was another lamia she was much younger the the one she hide under she looked around 15 years old but Chris could not tell because it was too dark.

What should Chris do?
1111.title: ...Im going but your staying here"

choices: use his amazing diplomatic skills to explain himself
try to take all 15 soldiers on (very unlikey he will win)
11111.content:
take my hand I'm here to help". The lamia looked Chris deep into his eyes. "trust me I'm hear to help i can get you out of here you just have to trust me". The lamia continued to stare at Chris, and then she spoke "You are the one who who came here first. yo...you brought them here" whispered the lamia "I didn't bring them here but i was the course of this, but i never know that they would do this" retaliated Chris "I'm trying to make thing right but we need to get out of here before more soldiers come" Chris stretched out his and towards the lamia, which reluctantly took it.Chris pulled her out of the hole, as she got out Chris go a better look at her. She had long fiery red hair that when all the way down her back to where her human half turned to her snake half. Her tail scales matched her hair being many shaded of red which glistened in the low light. her eyes where deep pools of sapphire blue. She looked 15 when she was hidden but no Chris thought she looked more like she was 17-18 years old it was her hight that made her look a lot younger then she was. Her breasts where about B cup in size.

Chris pulled his backpack off his back and pulled out a large black clock "here put this on and then we will get out of here".said Chris "Why would i do that" said the young lamia "Just put it o.." Tiny began to growl at a nearby tunnel, a faint glow was gradually getting brighter." Shit just put it on quickly" ordered Chris, the young lamia flung the clock over her shoulders. the instant the clock touched her skin the tail began to grow smaller and travel back towards her. her tail quickly began to change colour from red to a more pinky - cream colour, and her scales began to fuse and become one. Then her tail when it had almost reached her upper body it split into two fine long legs.

"what did you do to me where did my tail go" cried the lamia a mix of worry and anger in her voice. "its a complex illusion and alteration spell i will explain later but we must get out of here" with that Chris grabbed the lamia by the hand and pulled her down one of the many tunnels leading out of the cavern. Tiny followed at the heels of the lamia. "I think Deran's group went this way"called a voice echoing down the tunnel "Shit what happened here" said another "they all seem to be alive, we should search this entire place for the rest of the lamia and kill them for what they have done here" said yet another voice which slowly became quieter. The rest of the conversation was not heard as it became to quiet to be heard.

"so what's your name? because i can't call you her or she or lamia" asked Chris as they ran through the pick black tunnels "my name is Nel"said Nel "i have two questions one- whats your name, and two how can you see in these dark tunnels, humans eyesight is very bad?" questioned Nel "I'm Chris and i can see very well and i spent a lot of my childhood in these caves, i know them as well as i know the back of my hand". Within minutes they where outside to find that they where surrounded by 15 soldiers. "Chris I should have know that you where here this is your favorite place and this IS your horse" Said the soldier in front of all the others. He was wearing the same armor as the rest however he had a blue star etched into his upper left chest plate. "hello Captain Verdes"

what should Chris do ?
11111.title: Nel the lamia

111111.content:
"So Chris care to explain why you are here?" said Verdes "well i was showing my lovely girlfriend the tunnels and the crystal caves very far bellow the mountains" explained Chris "so your not here to help your monster scum are we, it just very convenient that I find you here so soon after we eradicated all those things." said Verdes "I don't know what you mean i was in the caverns from last night with Nel" Chris said acting coy. "I bet you where down there and you helped them, and that the girl behind you is one of those things" said Verdes his patience with Chris quickly vanishing. "look for yourself" says Chris as he steps to the side to revival Nel standing behind him in the black clock that Chris gave to her earlier her feet where pocking out of the bottom of the clock. "ok she is not one of those things but i don't recognize her where is she from?" pushed Verdes "she's from Mill Reach, now can we go? i need to get back to my store". "Fine i will let you go but I'm warning you if i catch you again I'm throwing you back into jail. Do i make my self clear?" "As clear as the Litas Lakes, goodbye Verdes" said Chris. "remember I'm watching you, YOU give him his horse we need to get back in there we have some monsters to hunt"

Chris waited for the men to go before turning back to Nel "my god that was close, that man will be the death of me" said clutching his chest. "I'm sorry i said those mean things earlier and thank you for saving me" Nel embraced Chris in a hug, Chris could feel her warm rip chest against his. "ummm yo.your welcome, ah-um" Chris cleared his voice and reluctantly puled away from Nel "where not safe yet we need to get back to my place"

Chris took his time getting back with Nel behind him holding on for dear life as they rode back to his home/shop. "I've never rode on a horse before its really quite scary" shouted Nel over the noise of the river which flowed next to the road. "don't worry we will be at the town in a few minuets" Chris called back "wait what you live in a town with more humans, no i can't go i won't go" said Nel as she began to push away from Chris, the horse knocked Nel's balance and she began to fall backwards off the horse. luckily Chris had amazing reflexes and court Nel by the coaler of the clock and was able to pull her back up. "are you ok?" asked Chris "yes I am now" answered Nel "don't worry about the town, the clock will make you blend in know one will know what you are".

As Chris, Nel and Tiny got to the town they easy got past the gates and back to Chris's house. Ben was waiting for Chris to return. As Chris entered his shop Ben lit up he was so happy to see his best friend "How did it go? did you get there in time?" pestered Ben "no i didn't, i was to late" Chris hung his head in shame. At that moment Nel entered with Tiny happily panting hugging close to her legs. "um so the shipment will be here tomorrow" Ben panicked as he quickly changed the subject, Chris looked puzzled at Ben's sudden outburst. "oh look Chris you have a costumer" Ben pointed out. Chris quickly put 2 and 2 together, Ben changed the subject because Nel walked in. "Ben don't worry she won't say anything she was the only lamia i could save". "no thats possible she's human she's got legs not a tail."stating Ben with a very good observation. "she's wearing an enchanted clock that makes her look human" explained Chris. "where in the hell did you get one of those?" "I made it obviously" "i knew you where good with magic but this is unbelievable thats so amazing"

"so this is Nel and Nel this is Ben" introduced Chris "now Ben can you not tell anyone about this clock it could mean disaster" "thats fine mate i will keep it a secret. I've got to get back to the inn my dad must be really swamped my now. Bye Chris" When Ben left Nel began to walk towards Chris when she just collapsed onto the floor.Chris rushed over to Nel and found she had collapsed from exhaustion, Chris proceeded to take her to a bed in the spare room.

115.title: other

13.content:
1. Kabol: Neko. Age: N/A. Human skin is a shade of tan leaning towards ebony. His hair is brown. His furry ears, hands and tail are black. He wears a brown fedora that borders being a cowboy hat, along with a matching trench coat and pants, and a mismatched black knee high boots. When Kabol was born, a curse was placed on him by an anthropomorphic witch. She despised humans, and anything related to humans, and when she found out that her bloodline bore humanity in it, she was livid. She cursed Kabol with immortality and amplified pain. A side effect is a special gift of unknown origins, so it isn't all bad. It's been so long, Kabol is now tired of it. For the first time in forever, he's heard of a warlock from far away who can lift the curse. He's ready.

2. Kesh: Neko. Age: 18. Human skin is white, but not ghost-like. His hair is black. His ears are a darker shade of brown than his hands and tail. He doesn't wear clothes, except for his pants. Kesh spent his whole life training to be a soldier. He can swing a sword faster than any man, block with a shield against blows as heavy as stone, knock an arrow and fire faster than a blink of an eye. But he's a cat in a humans world. He isn't trusted enough to lead men to their deaths, so guard duty is his life's calling. Or so he thought...

3. Noel: Neko. Age: 23. Human skin is white as the arctic snow. Her purple hair and blue eyes are the only things that are not white. She isn't allowed to wear anything, other than leather she wraps around places on her body. Her master, is a Vree, a large, bear like quadriplegic that made a meal out of her previous slaves. Once she figured out it was her turn, she ran, and has been running ever since. What ever will happen...?

4. Sheneshk: Lamia. Age: 27. Human skin is casually white. She has blue eyes and long blonde hair. He snake tail is dark green with a darker shade of azul striped down it. Sheneshk was sleeping in a tree one morning. She woke up to the sound of humans down below exploring. They looked under equipped for the dangers of your forest. Time to make quick work of them...
13.title: Hybrid (Lamia, Neko,

131.content:
Kabol paced back and forth across the forest terrain.
         When he heard there was a chance to finally end his eternal suffering, he left town almost immediately. The directions were simple: Over the hills and through the woods, to warlocks house we go. Followed by the wheels on the train go 'round and 'round. Followed by something, something, desert, something and he'll be there. Or he can just follow a giant storm over the skies of a distant castle. He's doing the latter.
         The hills were a breeze. Just an open plain outside the town. Was peaceful while it lasted, until Kabol forgot to bring his trust weapons. On his hips rested two swords. Yellow steel swords that were similar to katanas, but shorter and with no guard. He also had two retractable blades hidden under his arms, being prepared for the most dire situations.
         His ear twitched. A scurry across the grass. He pounced and cupped his hands, pulling out a small field mouse. It scurried int he air. Kabol shrugged and tossed it. It didn't do anything wrong. If he was truly hungry, he'd have eaten it. He's lived long enough to see there isn't any real luxury in food, except to the starving.
         He watched it scurry along the forest floor. Shaded and covered in leaves in twigs. That mouse must be on an adventure like him, but with a better view. As Kabol was watching, he noticed something moved across one of the patches of light on the floor. He looked up at the tall trees and prepared to draw his swords. It could be vree, or a cockatrice, maybe a wild cat even. He noticed a scaly tail sliding behind one of the tree trunks above. It was a... Lamia.
         Kabol sighed and dropped his guard. He pretended he was up to nothing. Leaves shook above, making Kabol roll his eyes. He turned around to see a lamia; Black short hair, green eyes, white human torse with leaves covering the breasts, and a dark purple snake tail.
         Kabol threw his arms in the air to his sides, as if he was going to hug, "Sup, naga,"
         The young snakewoman was taken aback. She hissed, "So you found me. I guess I was a little sloppy."
         "A little?" Kabol placed his palm on his face, "Lady, letting me see your tail was a little sloppy. Shaking the leaves just made you look stupid."
         She slithered closer. She was almost twice the size of Kabol. She smirked and started to strafe a circle slowly around him, "I wouldn't be talking like that. I've been hungry for about a week now, and nekos are my favorite prey."
         Kabol changed his tone to a higher annoying pitch, "I've been hungry. Nekos are my favorite prey." Kabol mimicked. He rolled his eyes again, "No wonder you're hungry, you suck at your job."
         "I'll have you know-"
         "I'll have you know." Kabol interrupted with the high pitched mimic voice.
         She hissed, "That's pretty immature."
         "Lady," Kabol pointed at her, "You freaking eat people, and you're judging me?"
         The naga had enough. She lunged at him with sharp claws. Kabol jumped back, drawing out his swords. The lamia raced towards him and did another dive. Kabol merely jumped to the side, dodging her. Kabol ran up and jumped on her back. He held a sword against her neck.
         The naga attempted to roll, but was stuck. She took the time to study her situation. There was fishing wire wrapped around a few tree stumps, and she was entangled between them. She looked down at her hands to realize they are stuck to her chest. They were not tangled, but Kabol's weight made it so that she can't lift them away. Due to her careless pouncing and lashes, she was trapped. Just as Kabol had planned.
         Kabol held a sword to her throat, "At first I was worried that a lamia wouldn't have fallen for this, but now I'm glad I didn't let that mouse trigger it."
         "Wait, wait!" The naga started to cry, "Please don't kill me."
         Kabol smiled. "Don't worry, I'm not going to cut your throat. That would be a waste of a meal." He said as he placed his hand on her back, revealing his secret power.
         The lamia gasped. She became weary. She can feel the world getting bigger. No! She was shrinking! Kabol opened his hand to see the small and frightened creature. Kabol shrugged and placed his hand to his mouth. He opened it, revealing his fangs and rough tongue. She tried to grab onto something but her tail was already in his mouth. He slurped her up to where only her human half was dangling out of his mouth. "What is this? No! Don't eat me!"
         "So here's the deal," Kabol began, his voice muffled a little by the frightened girl, "I'm not very hungry. But I am willing to swallow you whole, just for the sake of irony." His words made the creature struggle even more, "So what to do..."
131.title: Kabol The Neko

choices: He woke up with the naga climbing out of his lips
He woke up, filled by his digested meal
1311.content:
Kabol smiled.
         The naga between his lips took notice of its curvature and shook her head. She tried to pull herself from between the lips, She began to weep, "Please don't do it! I want to live!" Kabol began to slurp her more in his mouth, Her human belly passed through his lips. She pushed harder, begging again, "No! I'm sorry I tried to eat you! I'll be your slave, just let me live!" Kabol slurped again, feeling her precious good upstairs slide on his tongue. Only her head, shoulder, and arms were sticking out. She bit tried grabbing whatever she could. It was futile. She closed her eyes, "I'm scared!"
         Finally, Kabol slurped the rest of her body in. She laid on his rough tongue that felt almost like sand paper. The mouth was humid. She was already drenched in his saliva and some of her tail was dangling down the throat. She trembled in fear on the lukewarm tongue. The only source of light is from the parted lips and teeth in front of her.
         An entire moment of stillness confused her. For a second she even thought she had a chance. Kabol was merely using it to let the moment sink in. He sloshed her about in his mouth and savored her taste. Her human half tasted a bit salty, while the snake half tasted like venison. Kabol teased her by laying her on top of his teeth a few times, and nibbling on her. He can still hear he crying.
         Kabol leaned back his head, making the naga freak out and try to grab something. It was too late. with a single swallow, the naga was sent slithering down his throat. A lump was apparent for the widest part of the naga, but it disappeared at the base of the neck.
         Kabol was content he didn't settle with the mouse. He wiped some of his spit from his lips and continued walking. He can feel the naga bang against he walls of his stomach, he's sure she's begging as well. Kabol knows how it feels to be swallowed. Happened to him a few times. But the naga doesn't have any blades that she can cut out with, so she's going to have to settle with digesting in the remains of his lunch.
         He laid down, preparing to take a nap and letting his gut have all the energy it needs. He soon felt a few bumps. It was the naga trying to escape the stomach from where she came in from. Kabol poked below his ribs, "If you think you can climb out, try it. But you'll be going back in several smaller pieces."
         The lamia stopped struggling, letting Kabol forget about her and rest.
1311.title: Hunter became the hunted

choices: Cherish didn't return at all, and you're preparing to hunt her down
Cherish hasn't returned, but whatever. Forget about her.
1312.content:
Kabol hummed, letting the situation of the lamia sink into her.
         He sucked more of the naga in, hearing her scream and plea. He did it once more, this time engulfing her entirely. She hung on tightly to kabols small fangs; small to him, not to her. After feeling this, he tilted his head back and opened his mouth. She was almost free hanging, her human belly just grazing his tongue and her snake tail is almost down his throat. All it will take from him is a gulp or two and she'll be history.
         Kabol threw his head forward, and spat her out on his hand. "Now this si going to happen," Kabol smirked, "You're my newest friend. And by friend I'm using lamia terms. In other words: I'll tolerate you until I'm hungry.Sound good?"
         "Please turn me back to normal!" She pleaded, "This isn't right!"
         "There's just no pleasing you, is there?" Kabol said, "You ask that I don't kill you, then that I don't swallow you, now you want to be normal, next you'll be wanting a pony. No. No, no, no, I think you are staying like this. So what's your name kiddo?"
         The naga attempted to pry herself from his grasp, but to no avail. She gave it, sniping back, "Kiddo? I'm eighteen!"
         "Hello Eighteen." Kabol smirked.
         The snakewoman grolwed, "Smart-ass. My name is Sherheshk,"
         "Hello, Cherish." Kabol tossed her in the air and grabbed her with his left hand, "Well, make yourself at home." Kabol placed her in his pocket next to his heart and continued on his way, "Did I mention nagas are my favorite prey?"

         He walked until sundown. Cherish kept quiet, perhaps fearful of making Kabol upset. Kabol was at the edge of a forest. Just several dozens of meters away was a town full of anthropomorphic animals. Or people with animal features. He never understood the differences. His parents were similar to them, but he knows he isn't welcomed in that town. Beast and men do not get along. And when they do, it's an abomination. His mother was crushed to death by his own grandmother, who in turn placed a curse on Kabol. That was over two hundred-and-something years ago, Kabol still hasn't let it go.
         Kabol made a fire. Didn't take him too long. He's still brooding over being different from the anthropomorphs. The humans accept him as one of their own. Not entirely, but at least he can sleep in their towns. He rolled a mat from his bag and let out a blanket as well. He pulled out Cherish. She was sleeping, but not anymore. She started to panic, as if her time was up.
         To her surprise, she wasn't going directly to his mouth. He gave her several sniffs and whiffs and set her next to him on the ground, "I don't want to go to be hungry, and you aren't keen on getting eaten. So how about you go hunting for me?"
         "At this size?" She complained.
         "I don't see a problem with it. But if you don't want to hunt, I'll be sure to give you a warm place to sleep." He licked his lips. Cherish frowned and nodded before heading off in the woods. Kabol called to her, "And I have your scent, so don't go running off or I'm having slug-girl for breakfast."

         Kabol fell asleep in less than half an hour. A book laid itself on his face and the fire sizzled itself out.
1312.title: He keeps her for now

choices: He brings her back to her full stature, letting her get her things
He decides to finally swallow her
13121.content:
Kabol woke up.
         Something scurried in the grass. Kabol blinked and reached for one of his swords. He was relieved to see that it was merely Cherish coming back with several berries on a leaf. She looked almost as if she was struggling. The berries aren't heavy, but there's enough that it would take a bit of effort to move it. She dragged it in front of you and dropped the leaf.
         She fell over and started to shiver, "Please, Kabol. I'm tired, and hungry, and cold, and scared. I learnt my lesson, I just want to go home."
{indent"Grapes?" Kabol asked as he sorted through the berries. Where did she find grapes in the forest? Wait, are grapes naturally in the forest? Some are, but these are purple grapes. The kind you find in vineyards. "Where did you...?" Kabol looked in the direction of the town and shot his gaze back at Cherish. "You didn't hunt, you stole these from someone. Do you have any idea how much grapes cost?"
         The lamia started to seem worried, "I-I... I'm too small to hunt- to do anything!"
         Kabol laughed, "I'm just messing with you. If someone lost grapes to someone the size of my finger then they don't deserve the luxury." He started eating the food. The grapes tasted delicious to Kabol. He still thinks food is food, but that doesn't mean he can't enjoy it when he can.
          The lamia looked around nervously, "May I have some?" Kabol tossed a single grape towards her. The lamia thanked him and unhinged her jaw. She shoved it in her mouth and swallowed it whole. Kabol thinks he can compare that to him trying to eat a watermelon in a single bite. But he's mortal enough that his neck and jaw won't want to play along with that idea.
         Kabol finished all the grapes, and double checked the berries to see if they were poisonous before eating them. After having a late dinner, he is understandingly not filled. Kabol gestured his finger for Cherish to come by. "Alright, Cherish, you ready to sleep?" The woman nodded. Her gut was plump a moment ago, but now it seems that the grape went deeper into her. Most likely it's in her snake tail part thing. She slithered her way to Kabol's chest and tried to climb into his pocket. Kabol grabbed her tail with two fingers and pulled her out. "Are you cold blooded?"
          The woman hesitated at first, but she nodded.
         "Well, I don't want to roll on your in my sleep, so you'll have to sleep somewhere else. And I can't keep a fire, so let's improvise."
         The lamia was pondering at first, but Kabol already had an answer. He shoved her upper body in his mouth and slurped her in. She began to freak out, for quite some time too, but Kabol ignored it all and attempted to go back to sleep. The lamia, scared, curled up around under his tongue.

         Kabol woke up again, lying on his chest. This time it was the birds chirping and the dew doing whatever dew does that interrupted his sleep. Kabol sat up and stretched his back. His tongue felt sore, reminding him of his apparent hostage. He held out his hand and spat her on it. She was breathing heavily, enjoying the fresh air.
         "That was disgusting!" the naga coughed out saliva, "I never had such a horrible sleep in my life. Why your mouth? Do I look like a spider?"
         "I thought nagas liked warm, dark, damp places." Kabol said before setting her in his pocket and starting to clean up his camp. "All you need are six more legs and you're not too different. Now quit whining, and don't cry. Where we're going, we need all the hydration we can get."
         "Where we're going? Hydration?" She looked worried, "You mean the desert! No! Why? What about my home?"
         Kabol stopped cleaning almost entirely. His eyebrow twitched in disbelief. "Home? You mean to tell me you have shelter somewhere in these woods? Lady, I just slept on the cold hard ground. My back-" Kabol tilted his neck to the right, making several popping noises "Has kinks in almost every vertebra. My knuckles in my hands have their own headaches from the cold that my sore mouth protected your cool blood from, and all I get in return is you complaining. Yes. You're coming with me in the killer desert of death."
         The lamia shuffled her fingers together, "Can I at least go home and get supplies?"
         Kabol looked at her and thought about what he could saw or do. She might not return. If she doesn't return, he isn't sure how he's going to handle that. He doesn't want to go through the trouble of hunting her down when he's so close to his next part of his journey. Even if she does come along how is he going to keep tabs on her if she makes a move. But he alone doesn't have enough supplies to bring the both of them. Even if she is shrunken, he can't really take care of her at night, he could choke. He could take care of her now. She's edible enough.
13121.title: Cherish returned

choices: She attempts to swallow him when he dozes off
131211.content:
"You promise you'll come back?"
         The lamia looked up at the opportunity of freedom and nodded. "Yes! I just need to get some water and food. It shouldn't take more than an hour."
         "Good, I'll give you half." Kabol said, "I suggest you run really fast." He placed her on the ground and his hand on her back. Within a few seconds she morphed into her original size. He pointed vertically from the town, and continued, "I will meet you a little ways that way. And if you don't find me, I'll find you. Don't let me find you."
         Cherish nodded and slithered off when Kabol let her go. He continued to clean up the campsite, deep down wondering if she will really return. And why.

         Kabol sat at the edge of a railroad track, of a knocked over tree. The stump on my rump has so many bumps busting my hump, i need a jump. That was his attempt at rhyming to pass the time. Half an hours of work went into that. He checked his watch again. She's late, perhaps not even coming. He looks at his pocket watch, it has indeed been thirty minutes. He sighed and sat back. Maybe he was too hard on her. She hasn't eaten in a while and all he did was pick on her. He would apologize if he saw her again.
         He heard several twigs start to snap behind him and panting. That must be her. Kabol turned to see Cherish slowing to a halt next to him. "I'm..." She began panting and he can hear some harsh breathing.
         Kabol lifted his hand, "Take a breather. Alright. I want to say that I am sorry. I realize I have been kind of a jerk."
         Cherish rolled onto her back over the fallen tree, letting a large bag of hers hang loose on an arm. Her chest went up as she inhaled a large portion of air and calmly breathed it out. "Wait, you're apologizing to me? Even though I'm late?"
         Kabol shrugged, "I've been kind of a bully to you. Entangled you, shrank you, almost ate you, sent you on an impossible, made you uncomfortable. I've been rude." He shot his glare at her, "I'm not going to stop any time soon, just know I plan on toning it down a little."
         Cherish snuck her way under the log and next to Kabol, "Well... I guess I can thank you for not killing me all the times you had the chance. I've met people... I know people who wouldn't have thought twice about it." She laid her head on her crossed arms on the ground and exhaled, blowing some bangs off her forehead. Her brow raised. "You feel that?"
         Kabol could feel the ground shake beneath him. "That's our ride."
         He looked down the tracks to see a dreadnought train of dwarven design. The front was tall and had blades curving towards the top. Any branches it ran into was cut with utter ease. In the middle of the sleek bronze plated train engine round window showing the flames of the engine. At the top of the block like engine was a trail of smoke leading to the heavens. Kabol backed up a few steps and Cherish followed behind him.
         "Here's the plan," he said, "We'll late the train pass and get on the caboose. From there we'll ride it until we get to the Badlands."
         "I'm not getting on that!" She snapped back.
         "You shouldn't have said that." Kabol retorted, placing a hand on her human like belly and shrinking her down. He stuck her top half in between his lips again and grabbed her bag. It was heavy, and he's pretty sure it's full of mostly cans of water.
         The train passed by him at a quick pace, but not one that can be considered fast. He thinks he could outrun it, but he lacks the stamina to beat it to its destination. As the engine passed by, Kabol was able to see the cargo. There were no civilian passengers. There were Human soldiers inside the box cars and trolleys. After a few of them passed, flatbeds with mechanical beasts of dwarven designs. Tubes made to shoot rocks with gunpowder were sat stationary on a steel wagon with treads. There were two of them on each flatbed, a total of eight. War.
         Every time Kabol thinks of humans, he remembers the tales of how they pride themselves off of killing beasts. As if a naga, or a griffin was an actual trophy. The must know little of this land. Even though the vast majority of all of it was unknown, the humans see it fit to say it's theirs. Kabol never truly had a problem with humans. Not all of them are bad, only the ones with power.
         After the war-machines passed came several box cars of food, ammunition, even slaves. Kabol wanted to bite his teeth when he saw a whole box of anthropomorphic chained to the insides of wooden car, but the being between them convinced him otherwise. Finally the caboose was nearing. Kabol reached out his hand and held on tight to any luggage.
         He jumped lightly. His outstretched arm snagged a railing on the caboose, and he pulled himself and the bags to the top. He placed his bag on a decorative pylon on the top right of the caboose and the nagas on the top left one. The caboose was pretty damn decorated. If you're going to war, you better look freaking fancy. But metal railings aren't impressive when you can tell what you are sitting on is wood.
         Kabol pulled the snake girl out of his mouse and laid her next to him before returning her to her original size.
         "What the hell is wrong with you! Why do you keep doing that?" She growled, though he doesn't think she was as angry as she sounded.
         Kabol laid on his back and placed his hands behind his head, "What? You didn't like the plan so I improvised. Admit it, it made things a lot easier."
         She opened her mouth to say something, but kept silent before asking, "So how long are we going to wait on this thing. It's really creepy."
         "It's not an animal, it's a machine. So long as you don't fall between it and the tracks, it's harmless." Kabol placed his fedora over his face. The train was going slow enough that he didn't worry about it flying away. "And to your question, at this pace, we have six hours to kill."
         The lamia was silent. She knows she can't talk a convincing argument. She looked at Kabol and asked, "How do you shrink people? Can you teach me?"
         Kabol moved his hat up and looked at her, "I don't want to talk about it. Now let me take a nap."
131211.title: Going on an adventure

1312111.content:
Kabol felt the train hit a bump.
         His bones ached from all the rattling. He's been awake for a while, but silent for most of the time, as was his partner too. She laid facing away Kabol, her tail curled back under Kabol's feet. Kabol shuffled through his bag and grabbed out a piece of candy he had from the town days ago. He bit into the chocolate wafer, wondering why his companion is so silent.
          "Hey," Kabol poked her bare back, "You asleep?"
         "What do you want?" She said in a grouchy tone.
         "I noticed you haven't eaten since that little grape, so I thought maybe you'd like something." Kabol poked her back with the candy.
         She reached under her shoulder with an arm and grabbed it. She inspected it with a glance and a couple of sniffs, "What is this?"
         "People call it candy, chocolate specifically. It's something you eat."
         "I'm not hungry." She grunted.
         "Then pretend it's me." Kabol jested. Cherish turned her head and shot a look at Kabol. She narrowed her eyes, before turning back to the candy and ravenously biting it. The first few bites she downed too fast to taste, but once the flavor started to settle in she stopped almost abruptly. She looked at the chocolate wafer with wide eyes before chewing gently. Her eyes were wide with bewilderment. She almost didn't want to swallow because how good it tasted. She took another bite, closing her eyes to help savor the moment.
         She turned toward Kabol, "Chocolate? Do you have anymore?"
         Kabol smirked and pulled out a piece, "It's the last one."
         The lamia lashed her hand out towards the candy. Kabol reacted instinctively and withdrew his arm. Cherish nearly rolled onto Kabol, grabbing his arm wielding the candy. Kabol placed his free hand on her chest and pushed against her as he placed the wrapped chocolate between his lips. She stopped moving for a moment and retreated back into her corner and covered her chest, facing her body away.
         "Are you alright?" Kabol asked with the candy hanging from his mouth.
         "I don't like it when you touch me." She muttered, "I'm afraid you'll shrink me again."
         "Hey, hey," Kabol said softly with concern, placing his hand on her bare back. She winced and cringed, fearing what he'll do. He continued, "I promise I will not shrink you without telling you."
         The naga turned back, keeping her upstairs goods covered, she hesitated, "You promise?"
         Kabol nodded, taking the wrapped candy out of his mouth, "And you can have this candy." She reached out her hand quickly to grab it but slowed it down and held out her hand. "Before I give it to you, I need you to promise not to try to kill me while we're together. If you agree, I won't shrink you at all. And when we're done, I'll get you more candy."
         Her face lit up and Kabol set the candy on the carriage. She nearly tackled it. She laid on her gut and tore the wrapper off the candy as if it were a an insulting banana peel. When the treat was exposed, she bit into it excitingly and slurped it in within a second. She noticed Kabol was looking at her and turned.
         "What's wrong?" Kabol asked, able to hear the sound of her chewing.
         Soon she answered in more of a mutter, "You left my bra on the ground when you shrank me to get on the train."
         Kabol nodded in realization, "So that's why you were quiet; too busy covering up." Kabol reached in his bag and pulled out some bandages. He tossed it to her, "You can figure something out with that, right?"
         Cherish nodded with a hum, "Look away."
         Kabol rolled to face the woods. "I never thought nagas were so conscious about their parts."
         "Don't call me that. Nagas are an insult; something those humans call us. Just call me Cherish... I mean... Whatever, just don't call me naga. You can look now."
         "Have something against the humans?" Kabol rolled over to see her on her back facing the sky. Her breasts were covered in bandages. It appears she has used them all. She held her hands on her gut and fiddled her fingers between each other.
         She looked hesitantly at Kabol, "When I was little, a bunch of humans attacked the caves I lived in." She started biting her lips and looked back at the sky. "I was very young. I was playing hide and seek with my mom before they came, so I think I was the only one who got away."
         Kabol frowned and looked at the sky as well. "I'm sorry to hear that. Did the lamia do anything wrong?"
         "I don't even remember my mothers face, so I couldn't tell you. What about you? Do you think humans are okay?"
         "Not all of them are bad."
         "The Crimson Shields..." Cherish trailed off, "So, where are we going anyways?"
         Kabol sat up and looked around. He can see the forest start to clear up. He tapped her on the shoulder and pointed through the trees. Behind them lied a tower off in the distance that had what seem to be a black thunderstorm above it. It was far off. The skies above Kabol are cloudy but not bearing water.
         The lamia got up, straightening her elbows and resting on her palms. She looked back at Kabol, "That has to be days away. Why in Dawnwakes sake would you go there?"
         Kabol flicked his tail from side to side. "I have my reasons."
         "You feel like telling me, perhaps?"
         Kabol looked past her towards the tower for a few seconds before turning back to face her, "Nope!"
1312111.title: Getting to know each other

choices: The ground began to shake, frightening the vree
The lamia and neko prepared to fight
13121111.content:
Kabol looked at his pocket watch.
         The scenery eventually became much more bland. Sand dunes and rocks replaced the green trees. For as far as the eye can see there was nothing but several shades of brown. None of which matches Kabol's hat and coat. He placed it back in his pants pocket and poked Cherish to see if she was awake. There was no immediate reaction, but she turned and looked at Kabol and blinked. "Is it time?"
         Kabol answered positively and got to his feet. It is probably the worst time to be in the badlands. The sun is high above in the middle of the sky. Kabol changed his mind, this is the second worse time. Everyone knows that the most dangerous part about the desert isn't the heat. What's worse, he remember that Cherish is cold blooded. The forest's humidity made it feel almost as hot as the Badlands but here it is much dryer. And then there's night.
         Kabol could see the spire off in the distance. He doesn't know what is beyond the Badlands, but he will find out. The train continued its slow and steady pace, making it easy for Kabol to simply hop off. After a few steps forward he felt smooth rocks under him. The sleek ground slid from under his feet. He nearly lost his balance but managed to save himself from falling by leaning his body forward. He reached a sand filled pit at the bottom of the small slope.
         He looked around the rim of the slope and noticed that it wasn't that big. If he would have jumped any sooner or later, he would have missed it. It doesn't look naturally made either. Gashes were made along the sides, and in front of Kabol was a small cave. Spider! Kabol thought.
         He jumped out of the hole and noticed there were others scattered about. Spiders? Kabol thought again. Perhaps he was wrong. They were in rocks and hills. Long dunes trail in between them wherever sand was present, as if something was dragged through them. The holes seem to be dormant and weren't used in some time. Near one of the holes was a leather satchel. It looked like it was backed in the hot sun for months Cherish picked it up and sorted through it. She pulled out some spoiled food and a hot metal canteen. The satchel fell apart in her hands.
         "What do you think caused this?" Cherish turned to Kabol, placing the canteen in her bag.
         "Something I don't want to run into." Kabol answered, brushing off the sand from his coat, "Come on, we should start walking. The sooner we leave the Badlands, the better."
         The lamia slithered at Kabol's walking pace. She asked, "Are you sure you don't have any candy?"
         "If I have another one, would you let me ride your back for a little bit?"
         "No!" The lamia snapped, before turning her head away, "Well, yes. I would."
         "Sorry, don't have any." Kabol laughed.
         Cherish crossed her arms and pouted.

         After an hour of waking in the hot sun, Kabol noticed Cherish was sweating a lot and starting to breathe heavily.. The holes from earlier were less abundant as he continued deeper in the Badlands. Dunes have also become less apparent. They have been replaced by cliffs and cacti.
         Kabol took a break, leading Cherish to a cliff and letting her hide in the shade. She curled up and took all the space in it. Kabol didn't care too much, he just sat against her snake tail. She was panting too much to care, but she wrapped him up and dragged him into the shade with her. Kabol can feel the heat almost steam off her scales. Kabol handed Cherish some water from his bag and she drank half the canteen. "I'm sorry. I didn't mean to be a burden. But this heat just gets to me." She handed back the water and rested her head on a rock.
         Kabol patted the tail that coiled him. It's the first time Kabol was embraced by such a creature that didn't want to consume him. He scuffed, "How are you with the cold?"
         "Better than this heat." She's no longer panting, and her vision was fixed on a pile of bones. A few minutes pass and the shadow has inched away from the duo. For a moment, Kabol thought Cherish was asleep until she asked inquisitively, "Kabol, are there two skulls in that pile?" She pointed to the pile of bones. Kabol inspected it. Not only did it have two skulls of different animals, but it also had more bones than any one animal should have. Some bones even have blood on it.
         Kabol sat up and got Cherish's attention, raising his voice "We need to move!"
         As he said that he heard a growl from above. A shadow made it's way on the ground before them. Kabol couldn't distinguish it other than a blob, until it jumped directly in front of them.
         It was a vree. A brown bear like creature with long spikes down it's spine and ears the belong to a fox. It bore a slain coyote in its jaws that wielded two lengthy teeth at the end of a long skinny snout. The vree dropped the coyote and growled at both Cherish and her neko friend.
13121111.title: Badlands

choices: Kabol was soon able to see something, a hovel?
Kabol was soon able to see something, a group of vrees
131211111.content:
The vree snapped its jaws with a growl.
         Its spikes were bristled and her teeth, used to tear open prey before it has a chance to die, dripped with blood. Cherish released her grips on the neko and get in a defensive position to combat the menace. Kabol pulled out his swords and prepared to strafe behind the vree, using numbers to his advantage. Before anyone can go anywhere, the ground began to shook.
         The vree's piss yellow eyes looked filled with fear. The bristles lower to a more timid position and its neck hunched down. It whimpered and turned tail, running through the pile of bones and jumping from rock to rock in a scurry away from the den. The ground stopped shaking before trembling again, this time lighter. Kabol looked at where the vree fled and then back at Cherish.
         "Hey, I'd run from me too." He jested with a smile.
         The lamia slid closer to Kabol, "I've never seen a vree run in fear from something."
         "I'd like to refer you to my first statement." Kabol smirked and sat in the shade. The shaking in the ground can barely be felt now.
         "Do you think that earthquake was natural?" Cherish asked. Kabol shook his head. Cherish looked around in the sky, "The sun is going to set in a few hours. Do you want to start walking?"
         Kabol nodded and sat up. He climbed to the top of the rock he kept shelter under and looked towards the tower. It still looked days away. When he began this journey, he knew it would take long. However, he didn't think about bringing a companion, or how much of a burden they could be. He would have been halfway out of the Badlands by now. Kabol tried to think of a path from what he could see. Desert, rocks, desert, hills, dunes desert and more desert dune rocks. If he looks closer, he might be able to find a desert dune rocks on a hill. That could be the highlight of his day. This isn't going to be fun.
         "We're going to have to walk at a quicker pace if we want to gain ground by night. A lot more dangerous creatures come out, most are probably venomous if I know how deserts work. So It's best we hunt now..." Kabol stopped talking at the sound of what seemed like someone slurping noodles. He turned to see Cherish with the coyote tail sticking from her lips. She looked a bit embarrassed and swallowed the rest quickly. Kabol tossed his hands in the air, "Really?"
         "Sorry," She blushed. Kabol can see lumps crawl through her gut as the coyote travels deeper towards her snake bit.
         "I'm just upset you didn't ask if I wanted any," Kabol smiled and turned away, "Come on, we should get going."

         The sun was about to disappear over the horizon. The air already turned cold. Kabol and Cherish covered at least six miles this time. Something he could have done alone, so he was impressed his companion was able to keep up this time. He can see Cherish begin to shiver. "Are you alright?" He said.
         "Just a little cold is all. I'm fine."
         "I have an idea that could help us both." Kabol said. He stopped and jumped on her tail. He went to the back of her human torso and wrapped his arms around her shoulders and legs around her waist, proclaiming "Piggyback ride!"
         "Hey!" Cherish tried to shrug him off until she felt some of his body heat. He wasn't too warm, not much of his skin made contact other than from his open trenchcoat and hands, but he was much warmer then the air cooling around her. She stood still for a moment trying to decide what to do. "Fine," She muttered, "This is so insulting. I swear, if you tell a single soul-"
         "I'll take my chances." He smirked, "Okay, I'm joking. I won't tell anyone, and no one's around to watch."

         Kabol rested his eyes for a few hours. The only thought going through his mind was telling him how great it is to be a cat. The lamia continued on, going on any soft terrain she can find to help Kabol sleep soundly. Cherish tried her best to imagine Kabol as just a backpack that generates heat. His skin has made her feel warmer the longer he was on. The sun was gone completely, has been for a little while. The lamia stopped and shrugged Kabol awake.
         "Kabol. Kabol wake up. I'm tired and it's so dark I can barely see the ground." She nudged him with her head.
         Kabol opened his eyes and yawned, "Alright, I'll make a fire." He jumped off Cherishes back. She felt cold rush up her spine in the absence of warmth. "It might take a little time, but we'll be warm when we-" Kabol froze when he felt an icy touch. The snake tail found it's way under his coat and wrapped around his waist and torso. He found that only his arms and head were free from the snake woman's coils. She then rested her human half on her tail, facing down. She grabbed Kabol's arm and wrapped it around her human waist. She rested still after the whole ordeal and a smile crept on her face. It was her bodies way of reacting to a warm source. Kabol continued, "When we sleep. Okay then," Kabol managed to remove his blanket from his sack and wrapped it around her body and him, "I guess I have guard duty."
131211111.title: Foreshadowing a Means to an End

choices: Kabol and Cherish awoke to the ground shaking
Kabol and Cherish awoke to a peaceful morning
1312111111.content:
Kabol yawned.
         Stay awake you old goof. He yelled at himself inside his head. He's gotten pretty warm in the naga's coils. He's sure that the outer side of the twisted tail was much colder. He felt a lump travel through the tail by the side of his left thigh. That better not be that coyote, Kabol rolled his eyes.
         As he did he noticed something distant near his right. It seemed like an aura of light. He blinked the sleep out of his eyes and noticed there was also smoke. And when there's smoke, there's fire. And come fire comes people. And come people come food and shelter. He forgets what comes after that; it was either hospitality or hostility. Either one is welcomed at this point.
         Kabol patted Cherish's scales, "Cherish, get up." He whistled, "Come on, up up. Got nice tasty candy at home if you wake up."
         "Candy.." She muttered in her sleep and tightened her tail around Kabol.
         He felt an unnatural amount of pain go through his legs and body, "Ow! Too tight! Yep, you're crushing me. Now wake up." He held her nose between two fingers and closed her nostrils, while at the same time keep her mouth closed. Her eyes shot up and she looked at Kabol with a predatory gleam. "You're squeezing me. Also..." Kabol let go and pointed to the light and smoke. She lost the look of a predator and stretched with a yawn, soon remembering how cold it is. The tail loosened it's grip on Kabol but not enough to let him fall through. He caught his breath a little and continued, "There's a fire over there. That means there's other people, maybe even shelter. Let's go check it out."
         Cherish kept the blanket to herself, encasing her human half as she followed Kabol to the light.
         It wasn't too far, about a two minute walk. They got to see what made the smoke and light; a hovel in a pit similar to the den Kabol and Cherish shared during the day. It was built into the rock, using rock. If they were traveling here by day, they'd had missed it entirely. Kabol scratched his head, "Strange place to live. Let's check it out."
         "Wait," Cherish slithered in front of him, "What do you expect they're going to do? How would you react to a random neko and lamia traveling together?"
         Kabol hopped into the pit, "So long as they don't ask me if I heard about their spiritual savior, the All-Maker and the Duo I wouldn't care." The lamia followed as Kabol continued, "Worse case scenario they're humans that don't like company."
         "Yeah, because a human who likes company would live in an empty desert."
         Kabol took a deep breath and put on a smile before knocking on the door of the house. "Just let me do the talking."
         The door soon shot open. A woman, human with skin almost as tan as Kabol's, held a triple-barreled crossbow towards Kabol's chest.
         Kabol held up his palms, and in a panic, "Hello! May I interest you about our spiritual savior, the All-Maker and-"
         The young woman took the safety off.
         "We'll come back never." Kabol pointed both index fingers to the distance.
         "Zerah, is that company?" An old voice called. The woman, turned her green away and brushed red bangs off her forehead with a huff of air. Before she could say anything the old man said, "You know how much I love company. Let them."
         "Papa," She called back, "You can't be too trusting. They could be scouting for raiders. Let the cold take them."
         The old man got from his chair and walked towards the door. He pushed her from the door frame and shook Kabol's hand, "Hello, mister." He looked well for his age. Seemed that only his voice was calling him on his age. He had a few grey hairs on an otherwise jetblack hair. His skin wasn't as tan as the woman, making Kabol guess that he doesn't get outside as often. His blue eyes even seemed welcoming to Kabol. "I don't get much visitors, and I assure you there isn't anything worth stealing here. Come in, come in. Oh my..." He noticed the lamia and cleared his throat, "Hello, miss. You're welcomed in as well. Zerah, move the furniture to the guest room. The rooms will be switched for the night. Don't worry about her, she has her mothers will and features, along with her temper. But she means well."
         Kabol thanked him and walked inside. Zerah was pulling away two chairs from the fire and into another room. The lamia slithered in past him gently into a large open room. It looked as if it was built into the rock. In the middle of the room was a fire pit that the naga found itself sitting around. She kept the blanket on her human half. She looked up at the old man and shivered, "T-thank you."
         "Ah, she's cold blooded. It's a good thing she has you for warmth. Sometimes it gets so cold that water freezes. If she was a normal snake, or maybe even a normal human, she wouldn't have it this bad. I'm sorry, I tend to be a chatter mouth. I didn't even tell you my name yet. You can call me Fenrir good sir. And you are?"
         "I'm Kabol." He shook his hand again, following the old man. The both sat on the naga's tail as if it were a couch. "Thank you for letting us in."
         "It's my pleasure, sir. I see your naga has noticed the fire." Cherish gave a glance at the old man, but forgave his word in honor of his kindness. Kabol took a closer look at the fire. Instead of wood, it looked like ice. It also gave no odor. The old man continued, "Glass stone. Even the name is a conundrum. They last a long time too. Sorcerers, I tell you. One day they'll figure out immortality I tell you. Trader comes by every year or so and gives us some."
         "Why would he do that?" Cherish asked.
         "I guess there are just some people in this world who are good." The old man smiled, "You came at a good time. Zerah and I were about to have some coyote stew. Would you like to have some?"
         Zerah came in from another room and handed a bowl to Fenrir, "Papa, if we give them any, we will have nothing for breakfast."
         Kabol rose a hand and reached for his bag, "We have our own food, it's quite fine."
         The old man nearly slapped Kabol's hand away from the bag, "No. You are our guest. We won't allow you to eat stale food." He handed Kabol his bowl. Zerah, hesitantly, handed Cherish her bowl. Cherish thanked her. When Cherish started sipping the bowl, Kabol was the only one in the room that saw the look Zerah gave. She seemed almost angered as she returned to the room and continued cooking. The old man continued, "Does she have a name? Your naga?"
         "I call her Cherish." Kabol said.
         "She's a big woman." Fenrir slid his hand across her tail in a petting motion before stopping and holding his mouth, "Oh, I didn't mean it like that. Compliment wise. I was admiring her size, her stature."
         "It's alright, Fenrir." Cherish said, "Thank you for the compliment. Please don't call me a naga, or imply I'm his."
         The old man nodded his head, "I didn't mean it like that either. I meant, you know partner wise?" Kabol raised an eyebrow. The old man shrugged, "I guess I shouldn't have assumed. I wouldn't have blamed you. I've seen weirder couples."
         Zerah handed Fenrir a bowl of stew and sat on the other side of the lamia.
         For the rest of the night, Fenrir chatted up Kabol and Cherish about how he and his wife moved here to avoid raiders, robber and other human acts. It started to get late, Fenrir and Zerah went to another room to sleep, while Kabol slept on a mattress Fenrir made Zerah give up. Cherish cuddled with Kabol, sharing the blanket, refusing to become a further bother to the old man and his daughter.
         Before Cherish fell asleep, she whispered in Kabol's ear, "For a human, I really like that old man."
1312111111.title: A safe place for the night

choices: Kabol rolled out of the way, making the sandshire attack Zerah
Kabol was unable to throw it far enough, the sandshire got him
13121111111.content:
Kabol awoke the ground trembling.
         Cherish also gasped at the sudden shaking beneath them. The light from the windows was in Kabol's eyes but he can see Fenrir was sitting in a chair next to the fire. He was warming his hands before noticing the two jump up from their sleep. He rose a hand, "Don't worry, it's just a sandshire. They can't get us in here. Just be quiet and we'll be fine."
         Kabol at the man. He sat and acted as if this was a casual event. "Fine?" Kabol asked, "How can you be so calm?"
         The old man looked at him, shaking his head, "Honestly, I'm not. Zerah's out there. She went to catch breakfast but hasn't returned. I fear that she may be after the sandshire. She never forgave them for taking her mother." The trembling slowed for a moment before getting heavier. Cherish curled around Kabol. The old mans face looked curious. He stood up gently, "That doesn't feel right." The ground stopped shaking, only to return to a much more violent state, "Zerah!"
         The old man rushed out of the house. Kabol slipped out of Cherish's grasp and chased after him. Fenrir looked around, his eyes filled with horror. Kabol heard a call from the distance. He can tell it was Zerah's but he didn't understand what she said. Fenrir called her name again. It was silent for a moment. Kabol can hear Cherish slide our of the house. She was about to say something but Kabol gestured her to be quiet.
         Zerah's voice was heard again, faint, but Kabol can hear it, "Run!"
         Fenrir called back, "What?"
         The ground trembled again, more violent than ever. Kabol was knocked off his feet, so was the old man. Kabol got up to see that the ground started to crack at the sides of the pit. Kabol hopped to his feet. Fenrir wasn't so quick. The cracks traveled in Fenrir's direction and the ground opened up. What looked like a worm with seven flaps covering it's mouth emerged. Within a second it opened all of them at the same time, revealing a snake mouth inside, before charging at Fenrir. It slammed into the ground, engulfing him and disappearing as quick as it came. It's long body traveled behind it, covered in countless spikes.
         "Papa!" Zerah cried at the top of the pit. Her crossbow only had a shot left. The cracks in the ground soon turned it's way to the woman. It went around the hill. Zerah's eyes followed it, turning a full 180 degrees. She whipped back around and scream, "Run!" She jumped down and ran to her house. The hill she jumped off of started to fall apart. Kabol rushed and tackled the woman out of the way. Streaming behind him was the sandshire. Cherish moved out of it's way, allowing its open mouth to smash into the house, demolishing it.
         Kabol turned back to Cherish and repeated, "Run!"
         He got up and dashed out of the pit. He heard the lamia slither faster and pass him up. In front of him seemed to be a pillar and some ruins serveal meters ahead. He was about to suggest going there, but the lamia already was on her way there. Kabol turned his head to see Zerah is almost on his tail. When he turned back he can see Cherish is already crawling up the pillar. Then his leg started to sting intensely.
         He fell down. A shadow coasted over him as he looked to see a crossbow bolt pierced his leg. He almost cursed, but stopped himself when he felt a tremor. Zerah lost her footing and fell. Kabol looked past his leg to see that sand started to build up into a pile and race towards him. Zerah was right in front of him.
         He has an idea, and only one shot. He picked up a nearby stone..
13121111111.title: Sandshire

choices: It's been some time, Zerah finally pulled through
It's been some time, Zerah didn't make it...
131211111111.content:
Kabol tossed the stone at Zerah.
         It landed at her feet with a loud thud. Zerah looked back at Kabol. She smirked and rolled to his side. Behind him was an emerged sandshire charging at her with an opened maw. She didn't have enough time to dodge, and no bolt to fire at it. She was soon engulfed by the voracious beast, which soon disappeared in the ground under her.
         Kabol tore the bolt in half and removed it carefully before he stood up. Where Zerah was at was now replaced by a hole similar to what he fell in when he jumped off the train. Kabol felt sad rather than angry. He used to always be happy when a plan comes together, but he still killed a woman in sake of revenge. He looked up and was able to see the look on Cherish's face. She saw the whole thing. "You don't blame me right?" Kabol asked, taking off his trenchcoat and hat, pulling out his swords.
         "Hey, what are you doing?" Cherish called.
         "I'm clearing up my conscious." Kabol can't see any dunes. He can feel the shaking, however.
         "Kabol, no!" Cherish nearly fell off the column, "Run!"
         He pointed a sword at Cherish, "Be quiet, please. I'm trying to concen-"
         Kabol was interrupted by the sandshire emerging directly from under him. It reached meters into the air.
         At the tallest point, Cherish can see his sword hit the ground. "No!" She screamed as the creature sunk back into the ground. Cherish can hear nothing but silence. For the first time since she met Kabol, she felt alone and scared. She felt her heart sink and she wanted to throw up. Her eyes became watery. She almost lost her grip when the ground started to quake again. The sandshire emerge on the ground, spinning and twirling its body against the ground.
         Cherish felt angry towards it. Enough to be described as hate. Suddenly it started to roar. It was loud enough that Cherish held her ears. The worm began to flail from side to side before letting out a final bloodcurdling roar and laid limp. Cheris was confused, until she saw one of Kabols swords stick out from a side. Cherish felt a revitalized hope and crawled down the pillar.
         Kabol cut through the sandshire's flesh and crawled out. Its juices drenched his pants and fur on his ears, as well as his skin. He fell on his knees and screamed, "That freaking hurt!" He reached back into the laceration and pulled out Zerah. Both the woman and Kabol were bleeding, Kabol less so. The woman was much less responsive.
         "Kabol," Cherish rushed up, spreading her arms either for a hug or in disbelief, "Are you crazy?"
         "Don't touch me!" Kabol held out his hand and started to drag Zerah with the other one. "You think I'm crazy That s'um'bitch had circles and rows of teeth in its throat. This-" He pulled out a tooth from the side of his waist, "feels like daggers, and it's everywhere in there. The tube only got smaller."
         Cherish helped Kabol drag Zerah, "What about Fenrir."
         Kabol was silent for a moment, "He was in too deep. I... I don't want to think about what may have happened to him." Cherish looked sad, the shadow of her bangs covered half her face. Kabol continued, tossing Zerah on his shoulder, "Let's take care of her first. She's in shock. Go get my stuff and meet me back at the house." Or what's left of it, He thought
131211111111.title: Getting eaten for the right cause.

choices: Kabol has a change of heart and turns her to her original size
1312111111111.content:
Kabol cleaned Zerah's wounds.
         It's been some time since he brought her back to the ruins of her home. At least two or three hours. Her shock was worse than Kabol thought, making her drift into unconsciousness for almost an hour. She was on the table from the kitchen in the living rooms shade. Kabol's own person was also damaged and bloody for the longest time before washing up. The only wound that really bothered him was the one in his leg made by the bolt.
         Even after hours of inactivity, Kabol can feel a throbbing pain with each heartbeat. The curse was a double-edged sword. Because of it, he has hours of constant pain, but if it was absent, he'd have been dead. Not just now, but many times over. At least this time he has a couple of giant tooths to add to a collection. He scrounged his lips realizing this si the first time he kept a souvenir on his many adventures. Kabol heard the lamia slither over next to him.
         She looked curious, "You saved her, even though she tried to kill you. Why?"
         Kabol brushed some dirt from his fedora, "She tried to kill me, then I tried to kill her. I got even. Though I don't think she would've done the same for me if I'd have gone first."
         Cherish sat on her tail, "How are you still standing?"
         Kabol shrugged and put the hat on his head, "I guess I wasn't in there as long."
         "Don't give me that. You walked out of it with teeth stuck in you and bleeding just as much. How?"
         Kabol shot a glance to the snakewoman, "You're not going to stop unless I tell you."
         "So tell me!"
         Kabol hummed a thinking tone before answering, "Nope." Before the lamia can snap back, Zerah woke up. Her eyes shot open and she rubbed her head. She looked around, mouth agape as she saw her home in ruins.
         "Papa?" She looked at Kabol, "Where's my papa?"
         Kabol shook his head, "He didn't make it."
         "What?" She closed her eyes and shook her head, "No. No, this isn't fair!" She began to cry. As tears streamed, she reeled a fist back and struck Kabol. She ran into the kitchen and brought out a knife, "You left him to die! Get out!" Kabol was about to protest. He did what he could, and her refusal to appreciate it made him feel upset. Before he can think of something to say, Zerah charged, "Get out!"
         She went in to stab. Kabol tried to reach for her arm, but from his peripheral vision he can see Cherish reach in. She grabbed Zerah by her neck and held her off he ground with a single hand and an outstretched arm. Zerah tried to cut the lamia, but Cherish grabbed the hand with the knife and twisted it until the blade was dropped. "Listen to me you runt." The lamia's glare burnt deeply into the woman's soul. Cherish can see the fear and sorrow on Zerah's face, she enjoyed every moment of it. She growled, "I saw what you did to him, and I wish he'd had left your sorry ass in the worm. But if you're too heartbroken, or too stupid to see it, let me remind you. He risked his life to save you and you better damn well thank him."
         Cherish dropped the woman on the ground. She fell on her hands and knees and rubbed her neck. She didn't hesitate to grab the knife and stab at the snakewoman. The knife drew blood from the tail.
         Kabol reached in faster than the lamia and punched the girl in the gut. He grabbed her shirt and she quickly disappeared. Cherish thought for a second that she vanished in thin air, until Kabol sorted through the shirt and pulled out a shrunken Zerah. She looked confused, scared and horrified all at the same time. Kabol reached for Cherish and placed the frightened woman in one of her hands. "Cherish, I seemed to have made the wrong move when I saved her. This time, the choice is yours."
         Kabol folded her fingers around her newest prey and headed out of the pit. The last thing he saw was the lamia hungrily looking at the woman.
         Kabol scanned the skies. The sun was directly over head. Noon. It's going to be too hot for Cherish to travel again. He heard the lamia slither in the center of the pit, "So how did she taste?" Kabol asked without looking back.
         "I didn't eat her." She said. Kabol turned around and raised an eyebrow. She continued, "The poor girl lost everything in a single day. And the day is only half over. Can we leave? Find some other shade? This place is depressing."
         Kabol nodded, "Let me just get a few things."
         Kabol headed towards the house. As he was about to step inside, he heard crying. Zerah was small and weeping at the corner of the door frame. Kabol heard her cry the same word repeating, "Papa." She gasped when she saw Kabol loom over her. Kabol ignored her and grabbed his blanket by her. He looked around, grabbing the knife and a bowl on the ground and placing them in his bag. He grabbed another bag that hung off a nearby wall. "Hey! What are you doing?" She called when Kabol started scooping up the glass stone in his new bag, "I need those!" Kabol ignored her, heading into the kitchen and taking any spices she had. As Kabol passed her at the door frame she cried, "Wait. You can;t just leave me like this!"
         "Sure I can. I'm about to too. Just watch."
         "Wait!" She called again as he turned away, "If you're going to leave, then eat me!" Kabol stopped and looked back. She wiped a tear off a cheek with her arm, "If you don't eat me, then the vrees will. At least you'd remember doing it. Please, just don't leave me alone."
1312111111111.title: Decision

choices: To the next part of the journey!
Kabol woke up in a tight, squishy, moist tube. What could possibly...?
13121111111111.content:
Kabol reached in and grabbed the woman.
         She cringed in fear, possibly deciding whether to be chewed to swallowed. Kabol had no intentions of killing her. Zerah looked confused when she wasn't in his mouth, but rather back to her orignal size with her shirt thrown at her. Kabol turned and stalked out of the door. Before he got too far, he turned back and pointed to the direction from whence he came, "Go that way until you hit a forest. Keep going, not too far past it will be hills and then a town. Pack up and go." Kabol couldn't believe what he was doing. She's going to want her stuff back. He continued, "And if we ever see you again, you'll have a first hand look at what it's like inside a lamia."
         He turned away, refusing to see the woman's reaction. He did, however, see Cherish's reaction. A wide smirk. She let Kabol pass her and slithered at his pace, "She's going to die out there, you know?"
         "What makes you say that?" He turned his head. Cherish held up the triple barreled crossbow full of bolts. Kabol shook his head with a smile, "I guess it wouldn't make sense letting her keep that. Thanks for sticking up for me back there."
         She slung a quiver full of boats around her shoulder. "Thanks for trusting my judgement. She didn't deserve to be un-shrunk. She tried to kill you."
         "Sound familiar?" Kabol said playfully as he rose an eyebrow.
         Cherish pushed Kabol to his side in a friendly manner, "Whatever. Alright, I guess you have a point. Let's find some shade."

         Kabol found himself in her coil once more. It's been hours since he left Zerah in the rubble of what was once her home. They didn't find any good shade for about an hour. When they did, Cherish thought it was a waste of another hour to stay longer. Now it's night and Kabol was coiled up, even though the glass stone allowed him to create a good fire. At least the both of them traveled a lot of ground today.
         He can feel his warmth in her scales and body, and he enjoyed most of it. Wasn't worth his elbow room. Kabol saw that Cherish bore a smile, possibly from having a good dream, possibly for other reasons. The more Kabol thought about it, the happier he was that he let the lamia live. He still, however, can't figure out why she tagged along. His threats were intentionally unfounded.
